results.title: DreamWorks: Inside the Studio
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Venture behind the scenes and uncover the history and creative process behind some of the world’s most popular animated films with this fascinating exploration of the DreamWorks Animation creative studio.

Join special international DreamWorks guests Bill Damaschke (Chief Creative Officer), Kendal Cronkhite (Production Designer), Christophe Lautrette (Production Designer), Jason Schleifer (Head of Character Animation) and Doug Cooper (Visual Effects Supervisor) as they take us inside the DreamWorks phenomenon and explore how the animation and artwork has evolved over the history of the studio’s many hit titles.

Offering key insights into the creative history of the studio and exploring the artwork that has inspired artists and animators all over the world, these talented DreamWorks creatives will also examine the joint curatorial process behind showcasing the art form in the groundbreaking ‘DreamWorks Animation: The Exhibition’ shown at ACMI from 10th April to 5th October 2014.

results.title: DreamWorks: in conversation with Jeffrey Katzenberg
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
CEO and co-founder of DreamWorks speaks exclusively about creating, leading and inspiring the world’s largest animation studio in this rare one-off Australian event. A must-see for filmmakers, animators, fans and would-be moguls of tomorrow, hosted by Channel 10’s Executive General Manager, Russel Howcroft (best known as The Gruen Transfer’s advertising media personality).
Katzenberg began his career at Paramount Pictures before moving to Walt Disney Pictures where he is credited with turning the ailing animation studio around. Under his management, Disney produced some of their most critically acclaimed and highest grossing features to date, including ‘The Little Mermaid’ and ‘The Lion King’. He also secured a successful partnership with Pixar Studios and helped bring Miramax Films to Disney. Katzenberg eventually joined forces with Steven Spielberg and David Geffen to start DreamWorks SKG.
Under Katzenberg’s leadership, DreamWorks has become the largest animation studio in the world releasing 28 animated feature films, which have enjoyed both critical and commercial success, earning nine Academy Award nominations, twice winning Best Animated Feature.
In 2013, Katzenberg was awarded the prestigious Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for his outstanding contributions to humanitarian causes.
Together with his wife Marilyn, Katzenberg provides support and leads fundraising efforts focused predominately on healthcare, education, the arts and the environment.

Proudly supported by the United States Consulate General Melbourne.

results.title: DreamWorks: in conversation with Bill Damaschke
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Go behind the scenes of DreamWorks Animation’s incredible success story with one of the key architects of its amazing 20-year journey - Chief Creative Officer Bill Damaschke.
From overseeing the creative production and development processes for the studio’s feature projects, to shaping the creative teams behind each project and growing the studio’s creative talent pool, Damaschke has played an integral role in bringing the DreamWorks worlds to the big screen.
Damaschke joined DreamWorks in 1995 and served as a producer and executive producer on a number of the studio’s feature films before being named Head of Creative Production in 1999, Head of Creative Production and Development in 2005 and Co-President of Production for Feature Animation and President of Live Theatricals in 2007.
During his tenure at DreamWorks Animation, Damaschke has overseen the release of a range of key DreamWorks titles, from the Academy Award-winning blockbuster ‘Shrek’ in 2001 through to the highly anticipated ‘How to Train Your Dragon 2’.
In Australia to celebrate the opening of the ‘DreamWorks Animation: The Exhibition’, Damaschke joined us for this one off event to discuss his exceptional creative career, his central role in DreamWorks Animation’s future releases, and his insights into the creative hub of one of the world’s most influential animation studios.
Hosted by Walkley Award winning journalist, author, broadcaster and presenter of ABC News Breakfast Virginia Trioli.

results.title: Angelica Mesiti: The Calling interview
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery, ACMI and Ian Potter Cultural Trust
results.brief_description:
In this interview (filmed as part of activities associated with the ACMI Exhibition ‘Angelica Mesiti: The Calling’) the artist reflects on the structure, approach and the processes involved in creating the work.

‘The Calling’ is a three channel video installation that focuses on whistling languages, ancient forms of non-verbal communication which are still used in 2013 to communicate in isolated and difficult landscapes.

To conduct research for ‘The Calling’, artist Angelica Mesiti travelled to the village of Kuskoy in Northern Turkey, the island of La Gomera in The Canary Islands and the Island of Evia in Greece where whistling languages are still in use.

results.title: Closure
results.brief_description: A young girl reflects on her connections with her family and friends and she attempts to discover why she feels like she is being ignored. She focuses on the experiences from her past but continually feels an intrinsic connection to water. Only later does she discover why this is the case.

results.title: An Evening with Shaun Tan
results.creator_credit: Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
To celebrate the exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From Book to Film’ a special evening with the Oscar®-winning animator, author and illustrator, Shaun Tan was held on 24 July 2013. He discussed the making of the exhibition, talked about his body of work and shared insights into his creative processes.
Shaun’s books, including ‘The Rabbits’, ‘The Red Tree’ and the acclaimed graphic novel ‘The Arrival’, have been widely translated and enjoyed by readers of all ages. His work as a feature film concept artist can be seen in films like ‘Wall-E’ (2008) and his Academy Award®-winning animated short ‘The Lost Thing’, which he also wrote and co-directed.
In 2011, Shaun received the prestigious Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award in Sweden. His attraction to children’s stories with confronting or puzzling ideas is reflected in his work, which encourages dialogue between adult readers and younger listeners.

results.title: The Estate
results.creator_credit: Caswell Coggins, Mike Carr, Balletboyz, Crossfire and Channel 4
results.brief_description: A short dance piece set in an English housing estate. The choreography is loosely based on the idea of vultures circling a dying animal, feeling their excitement and anticipation as they gather to feed, waiting for the moment to strike.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Caswell Coggins, Mike Carr, Balletboyz, Crossfire and Channel 4

results.title: Acts of Kindness
results.creator_credit: Michael Landy, Pinky Ghundale, Film London and Channel 4
results.brief_description: A celebration of everyday acts of kindness that happen on London Underground every day of the year. The film originated from ‘Acts of Kindness’, a project by Michael Landy for London Underground, commissioned by Art on the Underground, London Underground Limited, 2011-12.
